preqs: One of BIO2011, BIO2810 or STA2216, plus six points of ENV or level two BIO

rules.ruleString: (Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {BIO1011} AND  Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {BIO1022, BIO1042})
(Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {BIO2011, BIO2810, STA2216} and  Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {BIO2%, ENV%})
(Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {BIO2011, BIO2810, STA2216} and  Must have passed an (I/W) unit in {BIO2%, ENV%})

description: This unit covers all major aspects of tropical ecology, explaining why the world's tropics are so rich and diverse in species, what factors contribute to this richness and how the interactions between plants and animals result in such complex relationships. We discuss biodiversity in the tropics, the variety of tropical ecosystems such as rainforests, savannahs, dry forests, montane tropics and peat swamps. The importance of climate, nutrient cycling, disturbance, and forest dynamics on the ecology of tropical plants and animals is a major theme. Conservation and management issues such as conflicting land-use requirements, logging and fire are also investigated in the unit.
